I appreciate that the BDMv2 format is awful but I'm not sure I agree with this, some of these changes are just confusing IMHO like device_type -> type while volume_type remains the same.

As awful as it is I'd stay with the original keys, hell it might even force someone to come up with a sane v3 format one day.

Okay, cool. FYI it's copied from novaclient, and I was on the fence about this too. I also agree that naming of the different '*_type' fields is poor. The one "feature" I did think useful was the 'id' field that allowed users to specify a name in addition to an ID. When every other field is a direct mapping though, this feels more rather than less confusing. As you've said elsewhere, if users want this then they can rely this functionality provided by the other parameters (--volume, --snapshot, --image + --boot-from-volume) to make their lives easier.

This is written after the below comment but to prove my point we would also need to add input validation for the following here in regard to a callers use of volume_type:

It can be a volume type ID or name.

It is only supported with source_type of blank, image or snapshot.

It is only supported with destination_type of volume.

So should osc do this input validation or let n-api fail the request?

I'm asking as I'm find with the microversion checking but input validation of these fields is going to end up duplicating a whole load of logic from n-api when we could handle and translate n-api responses instead.

That's always an issue with client vs server side validation. I'm in favour of limited duplication of validation where it saves the user some heartache (see e.g. '--status' flag for 'server list' command). Given this is a very limited enum value, I think this kind of validation makes sense. Ditto for version checks. Something beyond than these checks, such as checking for inconsistencies between different fields, is very much a nice to have and probably isn't worth the maintenance effort/test matrix. Let me know if you disagree.

doc/source/cli/nova-manage.rst.message:
This is (libvirt) virt driver specific. Could we instead namespace it under a suitable name, i.e.

  nova-manage libvirt get_machine_type  # or get-machine-type

Alternatively, we could make this more generic. Something like:

  nova-manage instances get-prop hw_machine_type

Similar to my comments in [1]

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/769548/10/nova/virt/machine_type_utils.py

> I think there's a potential that HyperV users *could* end up using these commands to move between the current generations of their `machine type` and any future generations if that's even a supported thing to do in HyperV.

I went and investigated this as part of my write up on UEFI and Secure Boot in nova [1]. In short, it doesn't sound like this is possible, at least not in a manner that we could support in nova. To summarize, This is in large part because (a) Hyper-V doesn't support this natively and (b) it would be hard for it to do so as the two generations are very different, akin to PC+BIOS vs. Q35+UEFI in libvirt world, with different disk types (IDE-based VHD or SCSI-based VHDX) thrown in for good measure. There's lots more info at [2], [3] and [4] plus an old conversion script at [5] to show what's involved.

All of this to say, I still don't like the 'machine_type' category (/o\) and don't want it to be a top-level command that users will see. I'd be okay with nesting it under 'libvirt' or 'db' or even some other generic section that I haven't thought of, though I think you said in another that 'db' isn't an option due to some weirdness needed. Perhaps this could go under 'libvirt' as a generic 'get-image-prop' command that only supports 'hw_machine_type' for now? I don't think it would be crazy amount of rework and I'd be willing to chip in if you agreed, as it would let me build upon next cycle with the things I mentioned above.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/776684
[2] https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/virtualization/hyper-v/plan/should-i-create-a-generation-1-or-2-virtual-machine-in-hyper-v
[3] https://social.technet.microsoft.com/Forums/windows/en-US/87a15b00-500f-4a31-90f5-02d8d12d45d6/how-to-convert-gen-2-vm-to-gen-1?forum=winserverhyperv
[4] https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/archive/blogs/jhoward/hyper-v-generation-2-virtual-machines-part-10
[5] https://github.com/JDogHerman/Powershell_Scripts/blob/master/Borrowed%20Code/Convert-VMGeneration.ps1

That's a fair point, but realistically it seems unlikely that Hyper V users would be using this functionality, no? If the generic approach works for you, I think that's  maybe the way to go? I'd be okay with some libvirt-specific code inside the implementation if needed (varying shades of grey, I know /o\)

Hm, you convinced me. The get-prop command would make sense and would be safe but the set-prop command would be a nightmare as we don't have a generic way to set image properties and deal with the consequences. So the set-prop command would be a lie as it would only support machine_type prop now.

I should've called this out earlier in the series but it isn't actually libvirt specific. hw_machine_type is also used by the HyperV driver, something I stumbled upon while writing the docs at the end of the series. As a result I moved the nova-manage commands under a more generic category and moved the util code up to virt. I can make this even more generic if you want but the update code has some specific caveats in it for machine type updates that I'd need to keep somewhere.

I think there's a potential that HyperV users *could* end up using these commands to move between the current generations of their `machine type` and any future generations if that's even a supported thing to do in HyperV.

Thinking about it some more I'm really on the fence about a generic set of `nova-manage image_meta` commands. It's possible but a load more work and code refactoring to include the specific hw_machine_type caveats somewhere. In the future I wouldn't mind following up and introducing such commands that could then replace some of the util code here but I've not got the energy to spend on such an endeavour this release.

It's also bad UX IMHO, having both get, update and list_unset under a single machine_type category makes it much easier for admins to follow the eventual update workflow IMHO.

Here's what the docs[1] say:

"A given Kubernetes server will only preserve a historical list of changes for a limited time. Clusters using etcd3 preserve changes in the last 5 minutes by default. When the requested watch operations fail because the historical version of that resource is not available, clients must handle the case by recognizing the status code 410 Gone, clearing their local cache, performing a list operation, and starting the watch from the resourceVersion returned by that new list operation. Most client libraries offer some form of standard tool for this logic. (In Go this is called a Reflector and is located in the k8s.io/client-go/cache package.)"

So a new item is not possible after this case because "the historical version of that resource is not available". But even if we lose some events in the watch, we will still get a fresh copy when we recreate the watch because it always sends an ADDED event when you start streaming.

[1]: https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/using-api/api-concepts/#efficient-detection-of-changes

Follow up to the above. We had a further discussion on #virt (not logged), OFTC network with the libvirt developer, Michal.  Summarizing here.  Adam, feel free to correct / append.

* The fact that there are two or more possibilities listed in the output 
  of domainCapabilities doesn't mean that an attribute can be set to
  both values at the same time.

* The enum "values" from domainCapabilities show what the host 
  libvirt/QEMU is capable of.  E.g. if <enum type='secure'> only 
  contains <value>no</value>, then Secure Boot cannot be supported with
  the given libvirt/QEMU.

* The values of the OS "loader" enums—'type', 'secure', and 
  'readonly'—are mutually exclusive.  I.e. 'type' can either be "rom"
  or "pflash", 'secure' can either be "yes", or "no", etc.

* The confusion was caused by the sentence in the documentation of
  domainCapabilities  
  (https://libvirt.org/formatdomaincaps.html#elementsOSBIOS):  "This 
  refers to type attribute of the <loader/> element".  Where the
  <loader/> element is referring to the libvirt *domain* defintion
  (_not_ the domainCapabilities), here,
  https://libvirt.org/formatdomain.html#elementsOSBIOS.

* Adam suggested a rewrite of the confusing sentence in
  https://libvirt.org/formatdomaincaps.html#elementsOSBIOS:

    - "This refers to type attribute of the <loader/> element".
    + "Each <value> element under <enum name='type'> represents an 
    + allowed value for the 'type' attribute of the <loader> element in
    + the domain definition. For example, the presence of
    + <value>rom</value> means that a domain definition can contain
    + <loader type="rom" ...>...</loader>"

(Which I agree with.)

[...]

 > All correct, although again here there is an ambiguity in that you
 > are referring to <loader> in the domain, *not* the domain
 > capabilities:
 > 
 > > * The values of the OS "loader" enums—'type', 'secure', and
 > 'readonly'—are mutually exclusive.  I.e. 'type' can either be "rom"
 > or "pflash", 'secure' can either be "yes", or "no", etc.
 > 
 > The values are mutually exclusive in the domain, but *not* in the
 > domain capabilities.  This reinforces the importance of carefully
 > distinguishing which is being referring to, given how they are
 > somewhat parallel in nature, on the surface at least.

Agreed.  I indeed meant the "mutually exclusive" remark in the context of a guest config.  But as we know, in context of "domain capabilities", we need to know all the possible/supported values.

Clarified by If527593ced072681130f97810fd839dfcda6a45d, this is just a generic test for *any* support by *any* machine_type for trait reporting. More specific checks will be carried out later once we know what the specific machine_type to be used is ahead of spawning the instance.

This is being used for the trait generation. An x86 host might have support for both x86 guests (via KVM) and AArch64 guests (via QEMU), but we might only have UEFI firmware for the former. I think I can do that in a followup commit to support parallelization.
Each of these steps would need to properly interact with the the director which handles the parallelization, making the director responsible for knowing when the step is complete.

I guess the main consideration is how long this step takes. We need to support configs with large numbers of worker nodes (e.g. 50 or more). That is why we need to parallelize things like the unlock, which can take a long time. If this step is quick, then having a stage with multiple serial steps may be OK, otherwise you will need to parallelize this. The parallelization in the VIM's orchestration happens within a single step. You will not be able to have multiple steps (or stages) running at the same time.

.zuul.yaml.message: Needs updating. No reason Alistair's follow-up needed to run py3 probe tests.

Nice!

For other reviewers, zuul job configuration is not so intuitive so just wanted to go confirm the docs and the output of the job itself.

So pre-run playbooks defined will be run after any per-run playbooks in the parent (https://zuul-ci.org/docs/zuul/3.15.0/reference/job_def.html#attr-job.pre-run)

Post-run playbooks defined will be run before any post-run playbooks in the parent (https://zuul-ci.org/docs/zuul/3.15.0/reference/job_def.html#attr-job.post-run)

However, and I guess obvously, the run playbook (can't be a list of playbooks) so replaces, if defined, the parents. (https://zuul-ci.org/docs/zuul/3.15.0/reference/job_def.html#attr-job.run)

Just confirmed so other reviewers don't have too.

glance/async_/flows/_internal_plugins/we.message: AFAIK, this is a refactor, unrelated to the actual change you're making here. Please split this out to a different patch to keep the functional changes separate from cleanups.
I don't know how you have used to do it in the Nova world, but leaving code behind that won't be called in any circumstance is normally quite frowned upon.

This is again the same pattern as seen in image_data.py, and is another good reason why that DRYing activity should stand on its own.

And yes, in Nova we definitely see value in separating refactors from functional changes, and setting up feature code to merge in as much isolation as possible for later clarity, backporting, and regression-hunting. We *do* separate things into patches that we land (tested) before we plan to use them, and often put a hold on the ones that shouldn't merge until the thing that uses them is ready or agreed-upon. It's more paperwork, but it's far easier to move trivial, obvious, and not-fully-related things out to separate patches where, once they are agreed upon, need not be re-reviewed while iterating on the meaty patches.
AFAIK, this is a refactor, unrelated to the actual change you're making here. Please split this out to a different patch to keep the functional changes separate from cleanups.

You could replace this with

  from keystoneauth1 import session
  from keystoneauth1 import token_endpoint
  from keystoneauth1.access import service_catalog

  ...

  def build_ksa_client(req):
      service_catalog_string = req.headers.get('HTTP_X_SERVICE_CATALOG')
      sc = service_catalog.ServiceCatalogV2(json.loads(service_catalog_string))
      identity_endpoint = sc.url_for(service_type='identity')
      auth = token_endpoint.Token(identity_endpoint, req.context.auth_token)
      return session.Session(auth=auth)

This seems to be a giant special case to avoid setting certain image properties which normally get set when we add the first location, is that right?

I would also expect that everything except the last line here is part of the refactor you're doing in other places where you remove the "if CONF.enabled_backends" branch. Thus, I would definitely expect those, along with this, to be in a separate patch that we can validate and test independently to make sure it doesn't regress.

> As you probably can see, the non-staging code has not changed. And no, not looking to split it across the whole codebase into helper functions. This will be much easier to clean up when it's all in the same place.

I can, but it's difficult to eye-parse this because you changed every single line while also adding new functionality. Separating this out into its own piece means it can be validated easily to have not changed (besides becoming an inner function that is called on either side of the "if not staging" conditional.

It also seems very odd to me to have something this deep in the bowels need to know that the staging store is special. To me, that indicates a layering violation, akin to your editor needing to know what filesystem is being used to properly save your text files. It's this sort of thing that I think deserves some discussion and review, on its own and not mired in the other discussion of how this distributed import should be done. If this was a separate patch, then we could have that discussion in a patch about just that topic.

> Mainly two fold, making sure we do not set properties like size or multihash yet as we don't know what their values should be and that we inject the needed config values to the conf when initializing the staging store on non-multi-store environment to make it possible. This was done in multiple (staging api + all the rest of the import jobs) places before but using the locations to track the staging data allows us to clean that up, like explained in the spec.

Well, it's clear that my opinion on this matter differs, so feel free to ignore. However, to my eyes, it's much more difficult to look a giant if statement (which only just barely fits on my 5K screen) and convince myself that it's correct. It's far easier for us to test and validate two smaller functions in isolation, along with the logic for why we call one and not the other.

This will indeed clean up even more once we get to remove the non-multi-store config model. Until the cycle we get to do that, the later part _is_ the staging code.

As you probably can see, the non-staging code has not changed. And no, not looking to split it across the whole codebase into helper functions. This will be much easier to clean up when it's all in the same place.

Mainly two fold, making sure we do not set properties like size or multihash yet as we don't know what their values should be and that we inject the needed config values to the conf when initializing the staging store on non-multi-store environment to make it possible. This was done in multiple (staging api + all the rest of the import jobs) places before but using the locations to track the staging data allows us to clean that up, like explained in the spec.

I've just filed a Nova blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/hyperv-rbd

About tempest tests: we have a Hyper-V CI covering multiple Openstack projects. For Nova, we're currently using LVM volumes but we do have os-brick jobs for other storage backends (e.g. SMB or FC). We're going to add another os-brick job for RBD.

About the docs: configuring Ceph is outside the scope of the Nova docs. Nova doesn't require any special configuration, as long as Ceph is installed and the host can access the volume provided by Cinder.

About Hyper-V testing, I'd say we have pretty good coverage. The Nova job uses 2 Hyper-V nodes, doing a full tempest run, which includes (live) migrations. The Nova job uses OVS (we do have another neutron agent) and iSCSI (lvm).

Other storage backends are tested by the Cinder and os-brick Windows CIs. The idea is that we have limited hardware resources so we're trying to have a reasonable amount of jobs. If Nova breaks one of the storage backends, we'll catch it afterwards when the os-brick CI starts failing. 

About the docs, that's the nice part, nothing has to be configured on the Nova side. All we need is for deployers to be aware that this feature is available.

Why do we need two transactions here?

I actually test this case. If I do not separate the clearing and the setting into 2 transactions, the test would fail like shown below. I will add a comment here
to better explain why we needed to break into 2 transactions. TY for bringing this up!


```
neutron.tests.functional.services.logapi.drivers.ovn.test_driver.LogApiTestCase.test_overlap_net_logs
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Captured traceback:
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    Traceback (most recent call last):

      File "/opt/stack/neutron/neutron/tests/base.py", line 182, in func
    return f(self, *args, **kwargs)

      File "/opt/stack/neutron/neutron/tests/functional/services/logapi/drivers/ovn/test_driver.py", line 230, in test_overlap_net_logs
    acl = self._check_acl_log(sgr)

      File "/opt/stack/neutron/neutron/tests/functional/services/logapi/drivers/ovn/test_driver.py", line 110, in _check_acl_log
    self.assertEqual(is_enabled, acl.log)

      File "/opt/stack/neutron/.tox/dsvm-functional/lib/python3.8/site-packages/testtools/testcase.py", line 415, in assertEqual
    self.assertThat(observed, matcher, message)

      File "/opt/stack/neutron/.tox/dsvm-functional/lib/python3.8/site-packages/testtools/testcase.py", line 502, in assertThat
    raise mismatch_error

    testtools.matchers._impl.MismatchError: True != False
```

The need to break this up into 2 transaction is needed because of the atomic behavior I expect to see, where the ordering of the changes should not be assumed.

In this particular case, txn 1 will clear attributes of acl rows, which is potentially the same exact attirbute/rows set via txn 2. The txn 2 actually checks if the attribute is 'cleared' before deciding to write to it. If what happens in txn 2 ever happened before txn 1 changes is done, this would spell trouble. See line 183 above for the exact place where this is happening.

glance_tempest_plugin/tests/rbac/v2/test.message: Glance must have some opinions about users with 'admin' creating images and what to use for the owner. These tests are run with system-scoped tokens, which don't have a project, and they don't fail like the SystemMember and SystemReader tests below.

Talked with Lance about this, and he's going to split these must-always-be-skipped patches to a WIP patch above this. These won't be enable-able for quite a while, so no reason to add to the review load and/or commit tests that we can't actually run just yet, IMHO.

Note for other reviewers:

These are effectively what we currently consider to be "admin" today, which is "can do anything." These are testing those assumptions today, which before RBAC changes, are true. The FIXME comments in these tests describe what will need to change when this class is actually scoped to just admin-of-a-project. In effect, the SystemAdminTests above (currently disabled) will validate the actual can-do-anything admin after that is enabled, when these change to just assert what we expect a project admin to do.
++ thanks for calling this out explicitly.

Note for reviewers:

These are the tests that matter the most (IMHO) in that they assert that non-admin users are able to do what they should, and not able to do what they shouldn't, which is largely stable between the secure- and legacy-rbac jobs, and the glance changes for enforce-scope.

ironic/conf/api.py.message:
I think the terminology "API user" is a bit overly-broad, and the option name is confusing.

Assuming this actually matches the implementation, I suggest ~"notfound_requires_system_scoped_authorization", default=False.

I think this is deserving of several paragraphs of operator-facing explanation. Improved text might be:

"""
When a resource does not exist, it is impossible to determine if a project-scoped request is has a relation to that non-existent of a resource.

When this value is set to False, project-scoped requests will receive "404" responses for nonexistent resources. This is considered "less secure" behavior, in that it may leak non-existence information, but it is the currently the default for backwards-compatibility.

When this value is set to True, project-scoped requests will receive "403" responses for nonexistent resources. This is considered "more secure", in that it is not possible to evaluate a project relation to a nonexistent resource in a project-scoped request.

This setting does not affect system-scoped requests--in either case, system-scoped requests are given nonexistence data when applicable.
"""

... as written I think my suggestion may be slightly wordy, but I think some text to that effect and level of explicitness is desirable.

zuul/configloader.py.message: Shouldn't this check that the project or tenant allow circular dependencies?

Specifying this in the tenant config was done in the spec. However there was a discussion on IRC a few weeks back with the conclusion that it's actually better to decide this based on the queue since circular dependencies operate in the same shared queue which makes this a natural choice.

This way it's more flexible as the project can decide without an admin while still keeping the possibility to disallow cyclic deps in a config project.

I don't think I fully understand this.  If we have a cycle A-B, why can't we enqueue C that depends on A?  Final queue would be: (A, B), C.

If the issue is that when we get to this point in the code after enqueing A we don't want to enqueue B using this method, that makes sense, but we have knowledge of the cycle, so can we use that?  I think this is safe if we proceed only after the cycle is complete.  How about this process:

* Add A, identify B as a dependency in enqueueChangesAhead, recurse into this for B
  * Add B, identify A as a dependency already enqueued, no action needed
  * Identify A-B as a cycle
  * Enqueue changes behind B
    * The full cycle has been enqueued, so we can safely enqueue changess behind it
    * For each member of the cycle, enqueue changes behind it:
      * (member=A): B is behind A but is part of the cycle, so skip
      * (member=A): C is behind A and is not part of the cycle, so enqueue it
      * (member=B): A is behind B but is part of the cycle, so skip
* Identify A-B as a cycle (we're back in this method for A)
* Enqueue changes behind A
  * We'd run the algorithm again here, which isn't necessary but should be safe as it should no-op.  Maybe we can optimize by checking history.

You are right. I think I did not really consider enqueuing changes behind with my Github centric world view ;)

zuul/model.py.message:
It looks like we disagree on this.  I will say that from my pov, it's important not to waste vertical space (I don't mean never add an extra line, vertical space can be really useful), but excess use of vertical space means I have to scroll more to read the code.

There is more than one way to write this in two lines.  Other Zuul contributors share your concern about scanning, and in Zuul they have chosen to adopt this practice:

if (something
        and something_else):
   do_things()

The Zuul project has adopted pep8 as a style guide, and we do generally adhere to that (including the frequently ignored "A Foolish Consistency is the Hobgoblin of Little Minds" admonition; we're not super-strict).  Pep8 does discuss this issue in this section:

  https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0008/#indentation

Where it suggests several solutions (scan down to the 4th verbatim block).  The 4 line version is not one of them.

Please do consider adopting that form of the 2 line version.  It is used by your colleagues already, I think it may address your concerns while also mitigating mine, so it may be a good compromise.

Nit: maybe consider a 2 line version of this?  Any of the ways to write this in 2 lines would more closely match the predominant style and conserve vertical space (if we did the whole method like this, it would grow from 15 to 26 lines).

To be honest I find this formatting much more readable than the 2 line version as you can better differentiate between the if condition and the body of the statement. In the 2 line version you always have to search for the end of the if condition "):" to see where the body line starts. I'd also find this method much more readable if it would take 26 instead of 15 lines and I don't see the point in saving lines of code in such cases.
This is where the conflict was; I verified no code changes.

elements/vm/block-device.d/10-partition.message: why p2? what is the final partition name we get here?

We are formatting the EFI System Partition which is created second and by default when parted is used it starts with partition number one. Here, ESP partition is number two. Refer to line no 24,25

Final partition name would be <loop device>p2. For example, if image is mounted at /dev/loop0 then root file system partition is dev/loop0p1 and ESP partition is /dev/loop0p2.

At this point you inject knowledge about your changes of the bootloader element into a *completely* different element.

When continue in this way, the list here gets longer and longer
and the dependency to the different elements is lost.

Why don't you put it separately? Why not in the bootloader element?

Why do you fix things in this way? What happens if e.g. one user needs the first partition as UEFI boot partition and tries to use partitioning-sfdisk for this?

... here is exactly one of issues just discussed: you assume that the UEFI partition is always p2 - which, depending on your use of the partitioning-sfdisk element might not be true.

Additional: Why do you split the mkfs of the two partitions into two different places? Why do you do it at this place and not at the place where partition one is formatted?
Can we break this var DIB_UEFI_ESP_SIZE out in to environment.d as something we export - it makes it a lot easier to find where the default value is set.

This will always return true due if $DIB_UEFI_SUPPORT is non-zero (even if the value is 'false').

vm/environment.d/50-vm is setting this environment variable to non-zero too.
